text:
Hi everyone, I’m writing and article and curious to see what you think…

When creating forms (demo, free trial, or any type of sign up form) do you feel like having _more_ fields is better than _fewer_ fields? Have you seen one or the other convert better?

Thanks!

elements.text:
Hi everyone, I’m writing and article and curious to see what you think…

When creating forms (demo, free trial, or any type of sign up form) do you feel like having
more
fields is better than
fewer

fields? Have you seen one or the other convert better?

Thanks!

text: Hey <@U02QWSD3BSM>, there's pros and cons to both. More fields obviously qualifies the prospect more, and gives you more data to understand your customers (if they sign up), but it may lower your conversion rate. If sign ups are my main KPI, then I keep forms punchy with just 2-3 fields. Less friction points for the prospect/reader to actually convert. It also depends on the environment and what the form is trying to achieve. For example, if it's a product sign up form that appears on a blog article, best to keep it short, whereas someone who is requesting a demo is a hotter lead and might be willing to fill in more fields. Interested to hear what others think.

elements.text: Hey

Interested to hear what others think.

text: More fields, fewer conversions. Especially if it's anything that's not autopopulated by the browser. There are better ways to get information than making the prospect fill out tons of fields.

elements.text: More fields, fewer conversions. Especially if it's anything that's not autopopulated by the browser. There are better ways to get information than making the prospect fill out tons of fields.

text:
Agreed on more fields, fewer conversions as the default.

However, it’s almost more of a sales question, though, imo.

For example, I worked at a website agency, and we had so many inquiries that we were wasting a ton of time qualifying them all, so we added a few more questions (size of your team, budget). This reduced the volume of submissions, but it helped pre-qualify the leads a little more.

text:
Much like <@U036K0S6AQJ>, I think I’ll give the standard marketer answer of “*it depends* on what you want to use the data for”.

In some cases [like <@UUH2ESL66> just said] we have added friction _on purpose_ to disqualify the wrong fit right at the start of a product sign-up process; in others, fewer fields → higher conversions.

text:
I'm not currently, but I've been there. What helped was 2 things:

First, use the Eisenhower box to prioritize what matters.

elements.text:
I'm not currently, but I've been there. What helped was 2 things:

First, use the Eisenhower box to prioritize what matters.

text:
But the roadblock to that is that EVERYTHING feels both urgent and important, right?

Second, the only way to truly decide what to focus on is to *find things that do more than one thing.*

If an activity only does one thing for your company, slot it lower on the priorities and "important" tasks are ones that help multiple people/customers/campaigns at once.

elements.text:

text: Send Hannah Mans a DM on LinkedIn. She's the best out there at this stuff.

elements.text: Send Hannah Mans a DM on LinkedIn. She's the best out there at this stuff.

text: We anchor hard into time spent using a custom engaged time metric. We also look at engaged time by 15 second time bands to understand drop-off. We compare this time against editorial metadata to understand if certain formats, categories, topics, personas, etc. lead to people spending more time with our stories. There is a pretty interesting correlation between time spent and engaging deeper. And it's a story that rings pretty true across clients. I do think that the qualitative measures several people mention above are pretty important too. No one metric can tell you a full story - it's about the tapestry of collective signals (at least that's what I think).  The notion of internal metrics is really interesting. These are softer signals, but answering questions like "was this harder than it needed to be, did we get energy from putting these into the world, could the process have been simpler" are publishing production discussions that people often neglect.

No one metric can tell you a full story - it's about the tapestry of collective signals (at least that's what I think).  The notion of internal metrics is really interesting. These are softer signals, but answering questions like "was this harder than it needed to be, did we get energy from putting these into the world, could the process have been simpler" are publishing production discussions that people often neglect.

text:
I'm going to go with "it depends" too. Depends on traffic temperature. Depends on what they're getting. Depends on what each of the questions are.
We have seen longer forms convert much better than shorter forms....the big caveat though is that we use multi step forms, aka <https://klientboost.com/cro/breadcrumb-technique/|the breadcrumb technique> and save the most threatening questions for last

text: Hi everyone! I'm wondering if anyone has any good resources for creating effective interview questions for copywriters?

elements.text: Hi everyone! I'm wondering if anyone has any good resources for creating effective interview questions for copywriters?

text: I wanna know what you learn

elements.text: I wanna know what you learn

text: I don’t know of any resources, but I can share my experience! When I was managing a team that included writers, I always got a lot of good insight by asking for how they liked to receive feedback and specific examples of times they received feedback and it was difficult to hear. It gives you some idea of how the editing process will go, and their overall appetite for feedback and improving their skills (as opposed to thinking they know it all and will be impossible to coach). Just one aspect of the job that doesn’t get addressed by portfolios and samples, but is super important for in-house writers.

elements.text: I don’t know of any resources, but I can share my experience! When I was managing a team that included writers, I always got a lot of good insight by asking for how they liked to receive feedback and specific examples of times they received feedback and it was difficult to hear. It gives you some idea of how the editing process will go, and their overall appetite for feedback and improving their skills (as opposed to thinking they know it all and will be impossible to coach). Just one aspect of the job that doesn’t get addressed by portfolios and samples, but is super important for in-house writers.

text:
Feedback is a big one for me as a hiring manager, too. I typically want to see a balance between holding their ground when it’s really important to them, and knowing when to pick their battles.

I also like to explore their experience with and/or perspective on:
• Taking complex information and turning it into words non-technical people can understand
• Connecting with people’s emotions, even in B2B - we’re still marketing to humans and there is an emotional component that is often overlooked
• Dealing with competing deadlines - often copywriters get thrown into a lot of projects that people want done “as soon as possible”. But everything can’t be done ASAP. So how do they deal with that so they don’t burn out, miss deadlines, etc.?

elements.text:

Taking complex information and turning it into words non-technical people can understand
Connecting with people’s emotions, even in B2B - we’re still marketing to humans and there is an emotional component that is often overlooked

Dealing with competing deadlines - often copywriters get thrown into a lot of projects that people want done “as soon as possible”. But everything can’t be done ASAP. So how do they deal with that so they don’t burn out, miss deadlines, etc.?
